qas.question: What was banned that led to the demise of medieval drama?
In what year did Elizabeth I ban religious plays?
In what year were religious plays banned in the Netherlands?
What types of subjects did dramatists turn to when religious plays were banned?
Where were religious plays banned in 1548?
What wasn't banned that led to the demise of medieval drama?
In what year did Elizabeth II ban religious plays?
In what year weren't religious plays banned in the Netherlands?
What types of subjects didn't dramatists turn to when religious plays were banned?
Where were religious plays banned in 1584?

context: The end of medieval drama came about due to a number of factors, including the weakening power of the Catholic Church, the Protestant Reformation and the banning of <a0_0><b5_0>religious plays<b5_0/><a0_0/> in many countries. Elizabeth I forbid all religious plays in <a1_0><b6_0>1558<b6_0/><a1_0/> and the great cycle plays had been silenced by the 1580s. Similarly, religious plays were banned in the Netherlands in <a2_0><b7_0>1539<b7_0/><a2_0/>, the Papal States in 1547 and in <a4_0><b9_0>Paris<b9_0/><a4_0/> in 1548. The abandonment of these plays destroyed the international theatre that had thereto existed and forced each country to develop its own form of drama. It also allowed dramatists to turn to <a3_0><b8_0>secular<b8_0/><a3_0/> subjects and the reviving interest in Greek and Roman theatre provided them with the perfect opportunity.
